Indications and doses

Fungal skin infections,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply twice daily continuing for 10 days after lesions have healed.
  • For children
    Apply twice daily continuing for 10 days after lesions have healed.

Fungal nail infections,

To the skin

  • For adults
    Apply 1–2 times a day.
  • For children
    Apply 1–2 times a day.

Vaginal and vulval candidiasis,

By vagina using cream

  • For adults
    1 capsule daily, ovule to be inserted at night as a single dose, dose can be repeated once if necessary.
  • For adults
    Apply 1 applicatorful daily for 10 to 14 days, alternatively apply 1 applicatorful twice daily for 7 days, course can be repeated once if necessary.
  • For children
    1 capsule daily, ovule to be inserted at night as a single dose, dose can be repeated once if necessary.

Superficial sites of infection in vaginal and vulval candidiasis, Vulvitis,

By vagina using cream

  • For adults
    Apply twice daily, apply to the anogenital area.

Prevention and treatment of oral candidiasis,

By mouth using oral gel

  • For adults
    2.5 mL 4 times a day treatment should be continued for at least 7 days after lesions have healed or symptoms have cleared, to be administered after meals, retain near oral lesions before swallowing (dental prostheses and orthodontic appliances should be removed at night and brushed with gel).
  • For children 2–17 years
    2.5 mL 4 times a day treatment should be continued for at least 7 days after lesions have healed or symptoms have cleared, to be administered after meals, retain near oral lesions before swallowing (dental prostheses and orthodontic appliances should be removed at night and brushed with gel).

Prevention and treatment of intestinal candidiasis,

By mouth using oral gel

  • For adults
    5 mg/kg 4 times a day (max. per dose 250 mg 4 times a day) treatment should be continued for at least 7 days after lesions have healed or symptoms have cleared.
  • For children 4 months–17 years
    5 mg/kg 4 times a day (max. per dose 250 mg 4 times a day) treatment should be continued for at least 7 days after lesions have healed or symptoms have cleared.

Advice when patient is pregnant

With buccal use or oral use

Manufacturer advises avoid if possible— toxicity at high doses in animal studies.

With topical use

Absorbed from the skin in small amounts; manufacturer advises caution.

With vaginal use in adults

Pregnant women need a longer duration of treatment, usually about 7 days, to clear the infection.

Advice regarding hepatic impairment

With buccal use or oral use

Avoid.

Contra indications

Known side effects

General side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: Nausea, rash, vomiting,

Specific side effects

commonOrVeryCommon: abdominal pain in adults, burning sensation at application site in adults, oedema in adults, pruritus in adults, taste disturbance in adults,

veryRare: diarrhoea (usually on long term treatment), hepatitis, rash in children, Stevens-Johnson syndrome, toxic epidermal necrolysis,

notKnown: burning sensation, erythema, hypersensitivity reactions, itching, occasional local irritation, occasional local irritation,

With topical use

Treatment should be discontinued if side effects are severe.

Directions for administration

With oral (topical) use

Oral gel should be held in mouth, after food.

With buccal use in adults

Place rounded side of tablet on upper gum above an incisor tooth and hold upper lip firmly over the gum for 30 seconds using a finger. If tablet detaches within 6 hours, replace with a new tablet. With each dose, use alternate sides of the gum.

Advice for patients and carers

With oral (topical) use

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer miconazole oromucosal gel.

With buccal use in adults

Patients or carers should be given advice on how to administer miconazole buccal tablets.

National funding/access decisions

Cautions regarding administration

  • Avoid in Acute porphyrias
  • With topical use: contact with eyes and mucous membranes should be avoided
  • With vaginal use: avoid intravaginal preparations (particularly those that require use of an applicator) in young girls who are not sexually active, unless there is no alternative in children

Advice regarding conception and contraception

Gyno-Daktarin damages latex condoms and diaphragms.

Unlicensed use

With oral (topical) use in children

Not licensed for use in children under 4 months of age or during first 5–6 months of life of an infant born pre-term.

With topical use in children

Licensed for use in children (age range not specified by manufacturer).

Information regarding prescribing and dispensing

Flavours of oral gel may include orange.

Profession specific information

Dental practitioners

Miconazole cream may be prescribed.

Miconazole Oromucosal Gel may be prescribed.

Exceptions to legal category

With oral (topical) use

15-g tube of oral gel can be sold to the public.

Prepared medicinal forms of MICONAZOLE

There can be variation in the licensing of different medicines containing the same drug.

Forms available from special-order manufacturers include: eye drops,
Capsule
Oromucosal gel
Cream
Spray
Powder
